claim: The JPEG acronym stands for a joint committee.

supporting.text: JPEG stands for Joint Photographic Experts Group, which is a joint committee formed by ISO and IEC to develop standards for image compression.

attacks.text: JPEG stands for Joint Photographic Experts Group, which is a joint committee formed by ISO and IEC to develop standards for image compression.
The acronym JPEG does not explicitly include the term 'committee', which weakens the direct association with a joint committee.
While the term 'committee' is not in the acronym, the 'Joint' in JPEG implies collaboration between organizations, supporting the idea of a joint committee.
The JPEG standard was developed by a working group, not necessarily a formal committee, which may imply a less structured collaboration.
Working groups under ISO and IEC often function similarly to committees, with formal processes and decision-making structures.

supporting.text: The JPEG standard was created by a collaborative effort between multiple organizations, confirming that it is indeed the product of a joint committee.

attacks.text: The JPEG standard was created by a collaborative effort between multiple organizations, confirming that it is indeed the product of a joint committee.
The acronym 'JPEG' stands for 'Joint Photographic Experts Group,' which is the name of the committee, not a description of its nature as a joint committee.
While 'Joint Photographic Experts Group' is the formal name, the collaborative nature of the committee still supports the idea that it is a joint committee.

supporting.text: The name 'Joint Photographic Experts Group' explicitly includes the word 'Joint,' indicating a committee formed by multiple entities working together.

attacks.text: The name 'Joint Photographic Experts Group' explicitly includes the word 'Joint,' indicating a committee formed by multiple entities working together.

The official documentation of JPEG refers to it as a 'working group' under ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 29, not an independent committee.
The term 'Joint' could simply imply a partnership or alliance, not necessarily a committee with formal governance.
Historical records show that JPEG was formed as a sub-group of larger standardization bodies, not as an independent joint committee.
